{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3030589,"name":"Aiden Pepoli","username":"aidenp621","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/b487fb/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-26T22:54:37.473Z","cooked":"

hello, this is my first year coding with LabVIEW and we are having troubles getting our robot to drive during autonomous. driving during teleop works just fine and the auto program labeled “default” drives just fine, but if there is any code other then the drive code in the auto loop we get an error telling us the loop that contains the drive motors as too much code or another loop is starving the program Ill provide a copy of the code.

You don’t need the wait statements with your drive code. The auto wait handles that.

Can you be more specific on the error text?

My LabVIEW is too rusty to give you much help, I bet @jdaming is right though. I do want to take the opportunity to encourage you to switch to Java, even if you have no experience with it you will find it significantly easier, not to mention every tutorial out there is in Java.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-27T03:49:26.552Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":13.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":406916,"topic_slug":"autonomous-drive-troubles","display_username":"Dan Erickson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49369,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/autonomous-drive-troubles/406916/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3030953,"name":"JeffB","username":"JeffB","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-27T13:43:10.875Z","cooked":"
aidenp621:

in the auto loop we get an error telling us the loop that contains the drive motors as too much code or another loop is starving the program

There’s a safety mechanism that kills values to your motors if you don’t feed them values frequently. When you look at begin, you’ll see a safety VI with an enable input.

In teleop, you don’t see problems because the teleop code gets called regularly. In each call, you feed a value to the motors.

In your autonomous, you feed a value once and then wait for 3 seconds. You’re wanting to drive for 3 seconds. Instead, you’re giving in that quick value, running into the safety, and being disabled for 3 seconds.

You can fix that by replacing the first section in your sequence with a for loop. Inside the loop, have your value and a wait for 50ms (instead of 3000). Run that for loop 60 times (60*50 = 3000 gives you the three seconds of driving).

Alternatively, you can disable the safety inside of the auton code and enable it at the end.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-27T13:43:10.875Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":10.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":406916,"topic_slug":"autonomous-drive-troubles","display_username":"JeffB","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25428,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/autonomous-drive-troubles/406916/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3031478,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-28T02:51:08.543Z","cooked":"

If I were you, first I would change that “Flat Sequence” to a “Stacked Sequence”.
Just right click on the edge that looks like a film strip and choose “Replace with Stacked Sequence”
This makes each of those “Frames” into it’s own separate numbered section.

So your issue is using that “Wait.vi” and feeding it a value like “3000”. Your auto is just going to execute that code one time then wait 3000ms doing nothing. This is what is causing you drive motor errors.

Here are pics of me duplicating what it looks like you want to do for each frame…

FRAME 0 - Run your Flywheel, HorizontalLift and vlift motors at those speeds for 3 seconds
Do not move the robot during this time.
So I put in a while loop that runs its code every 100ms.
So every 100ms we feed those values into the controllers and to the drive motors.
The safety config of the motors expect values at least every 500ms.
So you will not run afoul of motor safety.
Since the loops runs every 100ms I just count the number of the loop we are in to get close to the number of seconds we want to run this frame for. (ie It won’t be EXACTLY 3 seconds but close enough)

Frame 01030×601 13.6 KB

FRAME 1 - (I just duplicated frame 0 and adjusted the numbers)
Do nothing for 1.5 seconds. Don’t run any motors

Frame 1855×580 10.5 KB

FRAME 2 - Run the tank drive at 25% for 1 second

Frame 2853×583 10.5 KB

FRAME 3 - Don’t run any motors anymore - this frame just runs until Auto is over.

Frame 3858×577 30 KB

Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/autonomous-drive-troubles/406916/7","custom_user_title":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3031482,"name":"Jason Daming","username":"jdaming","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jdaming/{size}/137720_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-28T02:56:27.516Z","cooked":"

Nope on stacked sequence. Hides the functionality, easy to miss. Your current while loop / sequence size could easily be half of that.

If your code is getting big enough to need it you need more subVIs.

Oh for a few frames, sure but I have a 14 frame Auto (have had bigger), no way is that being kept as a Flat Sequence.

If you are going that big you really need a better system. I suggest a state machine or run the command based template.

AfterTen:

If I were you, first I would change that “Flat Sequence” to a “Stacked Sequence”.

There are exactly zero situations in which I’d agree with this information. There are reasons the SSS is hidden behind that odd workflow instead of easily found in Quick Drop or the palettes.

It’s far harder to see the code you’re working with. It’s far more likely you’ll make mistakes passing values between frames. It’s more difficult to debug yourself as well as have others look at it.

The Stacked Sequence Structure is one of the worst things you can do to yourself with coding.

AfterTen:

The safety config of the motors expect values at least every 500ms.

The idea is correct. The timeout is every 100ms.
